Description: Body sherd of Aeolian pottery lid with part of flange remaining on inside; exterior: from inside, part of tongue and dot frieze; frieze of pendant lotus buds and flowers; modelled, red painted, ridge corresponding to flange below; part of tendril (or circle) and dot frieze.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lemos (1991, no. 1103) incorrectly refers to this sherd when she actually means Museum of Classical Archaeology NA68. According to Dupont and Thomas (2006, p. 80, NAU12), the geophysical characteristics of the fabric indicate that the sherd originated in Aeolis.
Bibliographic references: Dupont & Thomas 2006 / Naukratis: Les Importations Grecques Orientales Archaïques (p. 78, 80, 82-83) (NAU 12)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GK.48)
